# Read or Write data from Apache Spark pools to a dedicated SQL pool

Article: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/integrate-sql-apache-spark-pools-azure-synapse-analytics/7-exercise-integrate-sql

from pyspark.sql import types

datalake = 'datalakecn32xts6vteh6'

customSchema = types.StructType([
    types.StructField("SalesOrderNumber", types.StringType(), True),
    types.StructField("SalesTerritoryKey", types.IntegerType(), True),
    types.StructField("OrderDate", types.DateType(), True),
    types.StructField("Customer", types.StringType(), True),
    types.StructField("Email", types.StringType(), True),
    types.StructField("Adress", types.StringType(), True),
    types.StructField("Quantity", types.IntegerType(), True),
    types.StructField("UnitPrice", types.DoubleType(), True),
    types.StructField("ShippingCost", types.DoubleType(), True),
])

df = spark.read \
    .csv('abfss://landing@' + datalake + '.dfs.core.windows.net/Allfiles/01/data/*.csv', schema=customSchema)
df.createOrReplaceTempView("sales")

We must run code that uses the Apache Spark pool to Synapse SQL connector in Scala. To do this, we add the %%spark magic to the cell. Run the following in a new code cell to read from the top_purchases view:

%%spark

// Make sure the name of the dedcated SQL pool (SQLPool01 below) matches the name of your SQL pool.
val df = spark.sqlContext.sql("select * from sales")
df.write.synapsesql("DP500DWH.dbo.TopPurchases", Constants.INTERNAL)
